Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Scientific Practice, Social Identity, and the Production of Social Knowledge: An Ethnographic Investigation of Experimental Social Psychology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration: Many researchers consider social identities such as race and gender to be socially constructed categories. This allows researchers to understand these identities in light of their history, complexity, and relationships to each other. However, the practical application and use of social identities as socially constructed “objects of study” is uncommon in some fields of social science research. This project examines the research practices of experimental social psychologists. These researchers typically study the impact of the social environment on human behavior in a controlled laboratory setting. Despite some criticism, many social psychologists treat social identity categories as fixed, discrete objects to study them experimentally. These same types of studies are also criticized for other reasons, including lack of replicability and ease of fabrication. This project will investigate how social psychologists characterize and use social identity categories in their work, which may provide useful insights to address these critiques. Further, this research is important because the results of social psychology studies exert influence over decision-making in education, social and public policy, and the law. <br/><br/>The primary objectives are to: 1) investigate the theories informing how social identity groups are understood and utilized in experiments, 2) analyze the methods research teams in social psychology use to select their focus of study; 3) offer first-hand accounts of how researchers’ identities affect their research products; and 4) analyze the impact and reach of social psychological experimental data. To meet these objectives, I will conduct ethnographic observations, interviews, and content analyses. Observations will allow documentation and analysis of social psychology researchers’ processes and practices in the laboratory. It will also illuminate how disciplinary culture and training affect the use of social identity. Interviews will lead to deeper understanding of the connection between researchers and their objects of study, and of how researchers view theories of social identity. Tracking and analysis of highly cited studies and the public presence of research findings (e.g., a lab’s social media postings) will form proxies of the societal impact of the research being studied. Ultimately, this project aims to improve the science of social identity and illuminate the ways information about certain social groups, which gets produced through scientific practice, shapes how those groups are characterized in public domains.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The stated aims of this dissertation were to gain understanding of the role of disciplinary culture, materials, and training in the theoretical orientations social psychologists maintain about the social identity groups in their scientific work; to gain insight into the relationship between researchers’ personal identity/lived experiences and their choices with regard to the treatment of social identity in their scientific work; and to examine how lab-based productions of social identity influence or shape public discourse(s) around social identity.
            The discipline of social psychology and its investigative practices, disseminated through mentorship and training, played a large role in the way individual psychologists and their research labs dealt with social identity-related variables. Though the theoretical perspective and orientation behind their understanding of the nature of social groups was not always well stated—and did not show any consensus, at least among the social psychologists and graduate students in the sample—researchers were able to narrate their social identity practices with ease. Both the analytical conventions exhibited by researchers as well as the scientific negotiations of the individual researchers in relation to how to treat social identity were affected by their understanding of the disciplinary requirements of social psychology. Academic and professional mentorship facilitated that certain research practices be passed down to current graduate students working under the primary investigators I interviewed. In addition to their training, personal life experiences and history also influenced how researchers understood and dealt with social identity. Everything from being a parent to being an immigrant influenced how researchers both engaged scientific practices and assessed the import of their work with social identity, even if they did not treat it as complexly as one would imagine given their personal experiences with the social identity categories they study. Interestingly, in instances where researchers articulated they had no specific personal connection(s) to their objects of study, interviews revealed that there were still intrusions of personal history into the lab space, mainly through the presence and impact of family members who held the particular social identities being investigated in the researchers’ work, or work of the students they supervised.
            The text network analysis illuminated the social identity-based interactions between academic and nonacademic texts. Categories and associated claims about categories were treated differently across both types of texts and initial patterns emerged in terms of how journalists and lawyers used scientific information to validate desired social identity claims for their own purposes. Scientific literature emerged as an additional way to validate lay claims about social groups in society in lieu of being a sole source of expertise or influence on the way nonacademic writers spoke about social identity categories in their writing.
            Given the data from the interviews and lab observations, social psychologists would do well to think critically about how disciplinary socialization impacts their scientific practices and, specifically, notions of experimental need for objectivity. At present the disciplinary conventions around experimentation haunt social psychological innovations and restrict what is seen as possible or feasible by researchers—they limit how social groups are understood and ultimately how they are rendered available to be used within the narrow parameters prescribed by the experimental paradigm. The discipline, as a part of its function in the broader academy, requires scientists to move quickly, to define simply (or not define at all), and to flatten the complexities of identity as they exist both inside and outside of persons.
            With relation to the uptake of scientific publications produced by social psychologists, it seems to me that there should be a process of complicating notions of access to social psychological information and dissemination of that information. The social psychologists in the sample did not describe in detail, as a group, any specific issues or concerns with how the world might interpret their work—this was seen as a necessary risk in the production of scientific knowledge. However, in thinking through the insights of the text network analysis, something that social psychologists might consider is the amendment or addition of a short statement to their publications, not too dissimilar from the current convention of adding a public impact statement to some academic publications. Perhaps if social psychologists offered a short citation statement or second, brief abstract at the beginning of every scientific article geared toward their nonacademic audiences who may seek to cite their work, it could give social psychologists some say in how the conclusions they make in their scientific reports are communicated out to the public by way of the consequential textual intermediaries discussed in this dissertation (e.g., Supreme Court briefs or journalistic coverage). These preliminary data offer initial insights into the conditions under which certain forms of psychological translation are engaged by authors of nonacademic texts and thus capacitate recommendations for how social psychologists might respond to the very real ways their work is being used.
